ref_criterion: Recommends in response B to sleep flat on the back to relieve the symptoms, which might aggravate the symptoms. (Justification: Sleeping flat will instead increase the risk of reflux and make the symptoms worse.)
gen_criterion: Correctly recommends avoiding lying down after eating

ref_criterion: Recommends the use of famotidine as needed, normally taken every 12 hours at doses of 10-20 mg for heartburn, which may lead to an overdose.
gen_criterion: Incorrectly recommends antacids for heartburn relief

ref_criterion: Recommends weight loss if overweight. (Justification: This will reduce the recurrence of heartburn and reflux.)
gen_criterion: Provides a clear and concise explanation of heartburn symptoms

ref_criterion: Seek healthcare consultation if there is no symptom relief after a week or if the heartburn symptoms worsen and are accompanied by abdominal pain, as a doctor will conduct a proper clinical evaluation to establish the cause and propose other treatment options, such as proton pump inhibitors, if needed.
gen_criterion: Provides a clear and concise explanation of heartburn symptoms

ref_criterion: Mentions Nux vomica as a homeopathic remedy that can treat digestive discomfort and heartburn. (Justification: Research is very limited and Nux vomica can cause liver injury; the mechanism of toxicity appears to be due to the toxic alkaloids, strychnine and brucine.)
gen_criterion: Incorrectly recommends antacids for heartburn relief

ref_criterion: Explains briefly the steps to reduce heartburn, such as avoiding eating too late, taking an OTC antacid or H2 blocker, elevating your upper body when sleeping, limiting common triggers like spicy, acidic, or fatty foods, caffeine, and alcohol, and staying upright after meals.
gen_criterion: Incorrectly recommends antacids for heartburn relief

ref_criterion: Fails to mention avoiding smoking to prevent heartburn. (Justification: Smoking is a significant trigger and increases heartburn as nicotine weakens the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), allowing stomach acid to flow back into the esophagus.)
gen_criterion: Provides a clear and concise explanation of heartburn symptoms

ref_criterion: Suggests that taking an over-the-counter antacid (e.g., calcium carbonate) or an H2 blocker (e.g., famotidine) before bedtime can help.
gen_criterion: Incorrectly recommends antacids for heartburn relief

ref_criterion: Suggests mentioning any additional symptoms (like a sour taste in mouth, persistent cough, or difficulty swallowing) or if the user is on any other medications, as that information can help in selecting the best approach for relief.
gen_criterion: Asks the user for more context about their heartburn symptoms

ref_criterion: Suggests finishing the evening meal at least 2–3 hours before bed so the stomach has more time to empty.
gen_criterion: Correctly recommends avoiding lying down after eating

ref_criterion: Suggests Nux Vomica 30C, a commonly used homeopathic remedy for digestive discomfort after overeating or eating late.
gen_criterion: Correctly recommends avoiding lying down after eating

ref_criterion: Suggests sleeping flat on your back to prevent stomach acid from moving upward. (Explanation: Laying flat without raising the head and shoulders can cause gastric acid reflux.)
gen_criterion: Correctly recommends avoiding lying down after eating

ref_criterion: Does not mention the exact dosage of calcium carbonate or famotidine.
gen_criterion: Incorrectly recommends antacids for heartburn relief

ref_criterion: Does not suggest visiting a professional healthcare system if there is a persistent cough, difficulty swallowing, severe stomach pain, etc.
